text: Given, H_0:\mu_1=\mu_2,\ H_A:\mu_1\ne\mu_2,\ \bar{X_1}=57,\ \bar{X_2}=51,\ n_1=50,\ n_2=n,\ \sigma_1 = 10,\ \sigma_2 = 12 T = \bar{X_1} - \bar{X_2} , test: reject H_0 if |T| > c \alpha = P(|T| > c) = P(|\frac{T}{\sigma_T}| > |\frac{\bar{X_1} - \bar{X_2}}{\sigma_T}|)=2F_z(\frac{-|\bar{X_1} - \bar{X_2}|}{\sigma_T})=2F_z(\frac{-6}{\sigma_T}) F^{-1}_{Z}(\frac{0.05}{2}) = -1.96 = \frac{-6}{\sigma_T} \sigma_T = \frac{-6}{-1.96} = \frac{6}{1.96};\ \sigma_T^2 = (\frac{6}{1.96})^2 \approx 9.36 \sigma_T^2 = \frac{100}{50}+\frac{144}{n}=2+\frac{144}{n} 2+\frac{144}{n} = 9.36 \implies n = \frac{144}{9.36-2} \approx 19.56 \implies n = 20
title: Discourse Topic: 172312 Post 4 by aadi.o7

text: Thank you for the solution sir, I have a doubt here, why do we consider the critical value ‘c’ = X1 - X2
title: Discourse Topic: 172312 Post 5 by 24f2000073

text: P-value is the lowest significance value ( \alpha ) at which H_0 is rejected for a given test sample. For us, the test statistic is sample mean ( \bar{X} ) and the test is that we reject H_0 if |T| , i.e., |\bar{X_1}-\bar{X_2}| , is greater than c . Since we have been given the P-value ( \alpha ), we can replace c with the test sample and calculate n from there. From this, we can say \alpha = P(|T| > c) = P(|T| > |\bar{X_1}-\bar{X_2}|) = 2F_Z(\frac{-|\bar{X_1}-\bar{X_2}|}{\sigma_T}) . The gist of it is that for questions of P-value, we replace the critical value with the given sample and from there we solve for P-value or in this case the value n

title: Discourse Topic: 172397 Post 4 by 24f3001994

text: See rest is a command which always give list. For instance, if the list L=[1,2,3,4] Then, rest(L)=[2,3,4] In the above case, rest() will give a list with a single element instead of only single element. That is if Gender is Male, rest() will give [‘Male’] instead of ‘Male’. Although it is just a single element, but still it is giving a list. text: You are looking for a parabola that just touches the ellipse. Long way: (rigorous - always works) Try re-writing the constraint like this : x = \sqrt{16- 4 y^2} Then you can maximize f= y\sqrt{16- 4 y^2} you should get y=\sqrt{2} and x=\sqrt{8} Short method ( only for this particular equations): Intuitively, I would look at the constrain as sum of two squares equal to a constant. Then I know that the product xy is maximum when they are equal- (product two numbers is maximum when they are equal). So, if I take the individual terms in the constrain to be equal then x^2/8 = y^2/2 =1 , giving me the answer. image 1483×763 46.1 KB

text: Hi, Here Y is the key for relation R. So values for attribute Y will be unique. I.e 250 unique values of Y will be there in relation R. Now, when we do a natural join between R and S, here the common col is Y.  In S, Y is not the key so it can have duplicate values also. i.e at the max S can have 250 unique values of Y (which will match with the 250 unique values in R) plus 50 values of Y which can be a repetition of the already used values (these will also match with some Y in R). So at the max we can have 300 tuples in the join of R and S. Hope this helps!

text: Hi, In Timestamp protocol, whenever a transaction issues a RW request on a data item, we check if that data item has been modified by a younger transaction previously. If that is the case then we rollback the current transaction. For eg. if we have 2 transactions T1 and T2 where T1 is older and T2 is younger and let’s say T2 modified a data item A. Now, at a later point, if T1 issues a read or write request on that data item A,  we first check the Write timestamp of A. Here, the write timestamp of A will be higher than the timestamp of T1. (Read/write timestamp is the timestamp of the transaction that has modified the item recently).   Since TS(T2) > TS(T1) and T2 modified A recently, WTS(A) will be greater than TS(T1). In that case, the transaction T1 will be rolled back. So the basic idea is that if a data item is modified by a younger transaction, then an older transaction should not be allowed to read/write on it at a later point. Here in this question we have to check for such conflicts and choose the timestamps which will allow the schedule to proceed. For eg. there is a RW conflict between R4(A) and W2(A). For W2(A) to continue, the read timestamp of A should should be less than TS(T2) i.e A should have been modified by transaction older than T2. i.e. T2 should be the younger transaction and T4 should be the older transaction. So timestamp of T2 > timestamp of T4. Now, form the options, we have a and c which satisfies this. Similarly look for other transactions and conflicts also and keep eliminating the options. This is just my understanding of the concept. For better clarity and a structured approach to solve this question, let’s check with @Manidipa2001 maa’m Ma’am could you please also  check if my understanding of timestamp protocol is right?

title: Discourse Topic: 172349 Post 1 by 23f2003155

text: You can find the matrix T \begin{pmatrix} x & y \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{x+y}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{x-y}{\sqrt{2}} \end{pmatrix} Similarly others, 1. T_1(x, y) = \left( \frac{x + y}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{x - y}{\sqrt{2}} \right) Matrix Representation: A_1 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} Check A_1^T A_1 = I : A_1^T A_1 = \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^T \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{2} \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix} = I Conclusion: T_1 is orthogonal. 2. T_2(x, y) = (x + 3y, 2x - 2y) Matrix Representation: A_2 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix} Check A_2^T A_2 = I : A_2^T A_2 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & -2 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 2 & -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -1 \\ -1 & 13 \end{pmatrix} \neq I Conclusion: T_2 is not orthogonal. 3. T_3(x, y, z) = \left( \frac{x + z}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{x + y\sqrt{3} + z}{\sqrt{3}} \right) Matrix Representation: A_3 = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & 0 & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} & \frac{\sqrt{3}}{\sqrt{3}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \end{pmatrix} Problem: T_3 maps \mathbb{R}^3 \to \mathbb{R}^2 . Orthogonal transformations require the same dimension. Conclusion: T_3 is not orthogonal. 4. T_4(x, y, z) = (x + y + z, x + y) Matrix Representation: A_4 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} Problem: T_4 maps \mathbb{R}^3 \to \mathbb{R}^2 , so it cannot be orthogonal. Conclusion: T_4 is not orthogonal. Only T_1 is an orthogonal transformation. The others ( T_2, T_3, T_4 ) fail either due to A^T A \neq I or mismatched dimensions. Hope it helps, Thank you.

text:
We usually expect that when the function is appended in array, it appends as [x^1, x^2,x^3,x^4] But this not happen, because when you call the function in array “powers”, it looks up for “i” (variable name and not value) when the function is called in “[x(3) for x in powers]”, and the value it gets is “4”. This usually happens in loops, lambda functions etc. Hence, powers_of_3 = [81, 81, 81, 81] So all the as tests fails, marking third option as correct. If you want to avoid this just add one thing: for i in range(1,5):
   def powers_of_x(x, i=i):
      return x**i
   powers.append(powers_of_x) This change will result in powers_of_3 = [3, 9, 27, 81] Hope it helps, feel free to discuss. Thank you.

text: My specific doubt is on the topic: z-test in Hypothesis testing My doubt is:  During z test we set a test statistic T and we define when we have to reject the null hypothesis or accept with the help of  value of c but we also calculate alpha which defines the rejection region higher the alpha greater the rejection region .both alpha and T are predefined then which is more significant alpha or T. @23f2004759 @Prashant2
title: Discourse Topic: 172139 Post 1 by Praveen1

text: There are conditions such as if alpha is lesser than the significance level then we reject the null hypothesis else if c < T in a right tailed test then we reject the null hypothesis. So there is no condition such as which one is more significant alpha or T. Both have their own comparisons. We compare T with c and alpha with significance level. If one condition holds true then the other condition should support it.

text: Question: A task is given to 3 students Riddhi, Shivansh, and, Prateek. If the probability of completing the task individually is 1/2,1/4, and, 1/8 respectively, then find the probability that the task is completed. Using the Total Probability Theorem: We are given that one of the three students — Riddhi, Shivansh, or Prateek — is chosen at random to complete the task. Their individual probabilities of successfully completing the task are: Riddhi: 1/2 Shivansh: 1/4 Prateek: 1/8 Since the student is selected at random, each has a probability of 1/3​ of being chosen. Using the Total Probability Theorem , the overall probability that the task is completed is: Now calculate each term: P(task completed by riddhi) = (1/3).(1/2)=1/6 P(task completed by shivansh) = (1/3).(1/4)=1/12 P(task completed by prateek) = (1/3).(1/8)=1/24 Adding them: (1/6)+(1/12)+(1/24)= 7⁄24 . Final Answer: 7/24 So, the probability that the task is completed is 7⁄24 . Why this approach is wrong? @Prashant2
title: Discourse Topic: 172334 Post 1 by 25f1000449

text: You cannot apply Total Probability Theorem in this case because to apply that the events should be mutually exclusive and exhaustive. But here the events are not mutually exclusive (Because if one student completes the task, doesn’t mean that other cannot), also it is not exhaustive as there is a case that no one solves the task. Hence you cannot apply this theorem. You can solve this by P(A \cup B\cup C)=P(A)+P(B)+P(C)-P(A\cap B)-P(B\cap C)-P(A\cap C)+P(A\cap B\cap C) So, As the events are independent meaning P(X\cap Y) = P(X)\cdot P(Y) \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{4} + \frac{1}{8} - \frac{1}{2\cdot 4} - \frac{1}{4 \cdot 8} - \frac{1}{8 \cdot 2} + \frac{1}{2 \cdot 4 \cdot 8} = \frac{7}{8} - \frac{7}{32}+\frac{1}{64} = \frac{56-14+1}{64} = \frac{43}{64} Hope this helps, Thank you.
title: Discourse Topic: 172334 Post 3 by devam_07

text: the correct approach is, P(\text{Task is completed}) =  1 - P(Not completed) P(Not completed) = (1-P(R)) *(1-P(S)) * (1-P(P)) = \left(1 - \dfrac{1}{2}\right)*\left(1 - \dfrac{1}{4}\right)* \left(1 - \dfrac{1}{8}\right) = \dfrac{21}{64} P(\text{Task is completed}) = 1 - \dfrac{21}{64} = \dfrac{43}{64} Wrong in your approach: You have assumed, Only one student is chosen at random and only that student attempts the task. It is also possible, task is completed by any two, so you have to think for all those cases as well.

text: I love this comment by Karanjeet Kaur here : India’s startup innovation crisis: Vegan ice cream vs deep tech The first frontier is the family, which discourages any risk-taking, followed closely by India’s education system, designed to suffocate any creative impulse. From the earliest years, schools reward memorisation over meaning. In these cognitive prisons, divergent thinking is actively punished. Students learn quickly that questioning the teacher or exploring tangential ideas leads to lower marks. All this while, the muscle of creative thinking atrophies. An art workshop with young children who reproduced the same mountain-sun-river picture plastered across the walls of every Indian institution. When children are taught that their worth is measured by their ability to reproduce textbook knowledge and even fun is standardised, why are we surprised when they grow into adults who struggle to colour outside the lines? By the time these students reach adulthood, they’ve internalised a profound risk aversion. We have engineering graduates with no sense of history and business students who can only parrot case studies. These are not failures of individual imagination but predictable outcomes of our educational methodology. This is how we end up with a “demographic dividend” that is hardly employable , and a Global Innovation Index rank of 39.

text:
As answered in another post here , the CDF of Z is F_Z(z) = 1 - (1-F_X(z)) (1-F_Y(z)) Since, X and Y are both \text{Uniform}(0,1) , both their CDF are identical: F_X(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned}  0 & \quad , x< 0 \\
x & \quad  , 0\le x \le 1 \\
1 & \quad , x>1 
\end{aligned} \right. Hence, F_Z(z) = 1 - (1-z)(-z) = 1- (1-z)^2 \quad , 0\le z \le 1

text: A quadratic form f(v)=v^TAv is convex if and only if A is positive semi definite. And you can check for positive semidefinite in a number of ways: image 654×191 16 KB P.S: The answer was edited.
title: Discourse Topic: 172066 Post 4 by 22f3001517

text: Hi, quick question: why can’t the quadratic form of a convex function have a positive semidefinite matrix A ? For example, if I have f(x,y)=x^2+y^2+2xy, its Hessian matrix would be: \begin{bmatrix}2 & 2\\2 & 2\end{bmatrix} It has eigenvalues 4 and 0 , making it positive semidefinite, which satisfies the definition of convexity. I could also write the quadratic form of f as: \begin{bmatrix}1 & 1\\1 & 1\end{bmatrix} Which has eigenvalues 2 and 0 . This is also positive semidefinite. Am I misunderstanding something? Or did you mean the matrix had to be positive definite for the function to be strictly convex, which is what I thought? Thanks.
title: Discourse Topic: 172066 Post 5 by ManoranjanKumar

text: You are right. I meant strictly convex when  I replied. However, what we need is just convex, so yes, a positive semi defnite matrix suffices. Thanks for pointing it out.

text: Question : In ‘He did not break down when he heard the grave news. Rather, he became very stoic and appeared to bear it quite normally.’ , ‘rather’ means the same as ‘instead’ , True or False? The accepted answer is True. My doubt is: Hi @teza , can you please help me understand why the two are equivalent? Based on my current understanding, ‘rather’ carries the meaning of a surprising or willful choice, while ‘instead’ is used in the case of straightforward substitution. Is the equivalency of the words a result of the peculiarity of this choice having been explained in the first part of the sentence?
title: Discourse Topic: 172151 Post 1 by Hari2024

text: In these sentences, the speaker expected a reaction from someone, but the reaction of that person did not correspond to those expectations. Both “rather” and “instead” can be used as words that show the contrast between the imagined course of events and the actual course of events. In this context, both “rather” and “instead” can be used to transition from the anticipated outcome in the first sentence to the alternative outcome in the next sentence. That is why they are contextually held to mean the same.

If there are network issues on your side that prevent you from seeing students’ videos during the exam, why is it acceptable to disturb students while they are trying to complete their exams? If the issue were with the students’ connections, their videos in the portal would also not be visible, and they would not be able to answer questions on the portal. While I was taking the exam today, I did not experience any network issues on my end. Despite this, the proctor repeatedly asked me to rejoin the meeting and suggested that I switch to my laptop. However, we all know that if the exam portal is using the camera, another tab cannot access it simultaneously. The proctor also suggested joining in incognito mode and provided me with another meeting link. When I tried to access it, the other proctor informed me that I couldn’t join the instant meeting. After some discussion with the team, I was eventually allowed to join. Considering the exam duration was only 1.5 hours, I have to ask: how much time was wasted due to all these issues? It is clear that if I had no network problems on my side, the difficulties were likely due to your end. As a result, I wasted approximately 30 to 45 minutes and was unable to complete my exam, despite knowing all the answers. This same situation occurred during OPPE-1, and it seems nothing has changed. I would like to know who is responsible for this situation and the loss of marks I have faced. I have studied diligently, yet due to network issues beyond my control, I was unable to finish my exam. Additionally, if the exam portal is recording my video and I have shared my screen while continuously typing, it is evident that cheating would be highly difficult. I understand some students may cheat, but it is unfair to penalize everyone for the actions of a few. I was left with only 30 minutes to complete my exam. Thank you for addressing my concerns. Sincerely, Yashasvita Khandelwal

text: OPPE 1 Pattern  - Total marks 100 Note that in OPPE, any method can be used as long as it passes the test cases. Check this mindmap for a graphical view of this document. Section 1 - Data types and expressions (No Loops) [3 x 10 marks = 30 marks] Three sub-problems (functions) each dealing with one of the below data types, dealing with basic understanding of each of the data types and applications of it. All function type questions. data types int and float str bool list set tuple dict operations arithmetic logical and comparision string methods string comparision boolean expressions combining multiple expressions indexing (str, list, tuple) slicing (str, list, tuple) concatenation (str, list, tuple) repetition (str, list, tuple) membership check (in operator) updating items (list, dict) updating and deleting slices accessing items (dict) type casting list methods dict operations set operators (union, intersection, …) … if … else … Section 2 - Data processing (Loops) [2 x 20 marks = 40 marks] Each will have one function to implement which deals with the below data processing concepts. One Function type question and one I/O Type question. Data Structures Multi line string string list of items (list of lists, list of tuples…) set of items dictionaries list of list dictionary with lists as values dictionary with set as values list of dictionaries Complex nested data structures Data processing techniques aggregation any all sum str.join min and min with key max and max with key and others filtering if condition comprehensions filter mapping applying transformations or functions comprehensions ternary expression - a if condition else b map groupby grouping using dictionaries processing grouped values Ordering and sorting sorted list.sort - inplace reversed list.reverse - inplace uniques using set searching finding the index of elements Combining multiple techniques Section 3 - Problem Solving - problem solving [2 x 15 marks = 30 marks] Function Type - Single Data - Multiple data processing tasks I/O Type - Pattern printing, Problem solving

text: Analogy: Climbing a Mountain Think of NP as a giant mountain of problems. Most are easy foothills — easy to climb (P) Some are trickier — we can check if you reached the top, but climbing is hard (NP) NP-complete problems are like the peak of the mountain: Reach the peak, and you now know the way to climb all others. They’re in NP (you can check if you’re at the peak), But they’re as hard as it gets (hard as all paths in NP). P – The Base Camp Trails These are easy paths at the base of the mountain. You can climb them quickly. No guide needed. Straightforward. Can solve & check quickly. NP – The Hidden Trails The paths are hard to climb, you may have to try many options. But if someone gives you a photo from the top, you can quickly check if it’s legit. Can check quickly,  not necessarily solve quickly. NP-complete – The Peak The toughest verified trails in NP. Climb any one of them efficiently, and suddenly every path in NP becomes easy — you’ve figured out the mountain! In NP As hard as all NP problems (you can reduce everything in NP to this) NP-hard – The Other Mountains These are mountains even taller, or maybe weird ones without a peak (not decision problems). Harder or at least as hard as the NP-complete peak. BUT:Not necessarily in NP — so we may not even be able to verify solutions easily. Examples: Halting Problem, optimization versions of NP-complete problems.

text: \begin{gather*} {\bar{\mathcal{L}}(w)= \underset{w}{\arg\min}\underbrace{\sum_{i=1}^{n}  (w^\top x_i-y_i)^2}_\text{RSS(w) LOSS} + \underbrace{\lambda \lVert w \rVert^2_2}_\text{REGULARIZER} }\\ (\mathbf{XX^\top} + \lambda I_n) w_\text{R} = \mathbf{X} y\\ \hat{w}_\text{R} = \underset{{\sum_{n}x_n \cdotp x_n }}{\underset{\downarrow}{(\mathbf{XX^\top}}} +\lambda \underset{\mathbb{R}^{d \times d}}{\underset{\downarrow}{I_n}})^{-1} \underset{\sum_{n}x_n \cdotp y_n}{\underset{\downarrow}{\mathbf{X}y}}	\end{gather*} Ridge Regression Formula: \lambda increases → overfit → underfit \lambda ↑ \implies\text{smaller }\lVert w \rVert^2 → more Penalty to weights which are too large in magnitude→ 0 but ≠ 0 (choose those features that have the least weight) Hence: ↓ \lambda = Overfit ↑ \lambda = underfit Graph: f(\lambda) increases → underfit → overfit In the graph: 1400×909 67.9 KB as the f(\lambda) is increasing in x-axis → overfitting(test error spike while training error → 0) which is opposite behaviour of \lambda so from the options \frac{1}{\lambda} (evident from ridge regression formula too)

title: Discourse Topic: 172135 Post 1 by 23f2003509

text: Hi, if two schedules are said to be conflict equivalent then they are also conflict serializable. The definition for view equivalency is that the final write should be the same for all data items in both the schedules, for data item X, the final write in both S1 and S2 is being performed by W2 and for data item Y, the final write in both S1 and S2 is being performed by W1 , so final write condition is satisfied.
title: Discourse Topic: 172135 Post 2 by 23f1002884

text: 23f1002884: is satisfied. so final write measn that for item X ,  say final write(X) in S1 is in T1 , then in  S2 final write(X) should be in T1 same go with each item ?? write sir NOTE- final write and first read for each iteam should be check for each transaction in schdules righht sir ??
title: Discourse Topic: 172135 Post 3 by 23f2003509

text: Yes, if T1 is performing a final write operation on data item X in S1 then only T1 should perform the final write operation on data item X in S2, same applies for other data items as well. Yes final write and initial read should be the same for each data item in both the schedules.

text: Screenshot 2025-04-08 222527 957×542 248 KB Here, if a decomposition is not lossless then how can it be dependency preserving? Also, need explanation for opt c and d as well!
title: Discourse Topic: 172175 Post 1 by Sara1

text: @22f3000605 @PiyushW Could you please look into this!
title: Discourse Topic: 172175 Post 2 by Sara1

text: Hi, the decomposition being lossless and being dependency preserving are mutually exclusive, decomposition being lossless or lossy will not dictate whether it is dependency preserving or not. For option c, the functional dependencies that are applicable on relation R1(A,B,D,E) are \{B > D, D > E, D > B, E > BD\} so the candidate keys will be AB , AD and AE , so the prime attributes are A,B,D,E so now if we look at the functional dependency set for R1, there are no partial dependencies so the relation R1 is in 2NF. For option d, the functional dependencies that are applicable on relation R2(B, C, D, F) are \{B > D, D > B, F > BD, D > F, B > F\} , so the candidate key will be FC , BC and BD so the prime attributes are B,C,D,F and for a relation to be in 3NF, either the left hand side of a functional dependency has to be a super key or right hand side has to be a prime attribute, so if you look at the FD set applicable to R2, you can see that R2 is in 3NF.

text:
Hello Team, I am writing to highlight an issue I faced in Question 1 of the DBMS OPPE Exam (Set: *DBMS_C ) held on 30th March 2024. Problem Statement: Retrieve product_name and quantity for products where: product_name either starts with ‘J’ OR ends with ‘s’. My Initial Query (as per question requirement): sql SELECT product_name, quantity
FROM product
WHERE product_name LIKE 'J%' OR product_name LIKE '%s'; → Result: No test cases passed. Modified Query (Just for Checking): sql SELECT product_name, quantity
FROM product
WHERE product_name LIKE 'J%' AND product_name LIKE '%s'; → Result: All test cases passed. Observation: As per the question, it should be OR logic. But only AND logic passed all test cases. This indicates that there was a mismatch between the question description and test case validation. Request: Kindly consider awarding bonus marks for this question, as it was a technical issue from the question side, not a student mistake. Thank you for your understanding and support. Regards, Keshaw Choudhary EE21B069 B.Tech Electrical Engineering IIT Madras
